description: A hearty, comforting one-pot dish where green bananas (matooke) and beans are cooked together until tender, creating a thick, savory stew. The matooke absorbs the flavorful bean broth while becoming soft and creamy, resulting in a complete, nutritious meal that embodies Ugandan home cooking at its most comforting. This is the ultimate breakfast katogo that provides sustained energy throughout the day.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Katogo is the quintessential Ugandan comfort food, famously eaten as a substantial breakfast that can power you through until evening. The matooke and beans version is particularly beloved in Central Uganda. It represents the wisdom of one-pot cooking where ingredients cook together, exchanging flavors. Traditionally, katogo is cooked overnight on low heat or early in the morning to be ready for breakfast. It's a dish that says 'home' to most Ugandans and is often associated with weekend family meals and special morning gatherings.

ingredients.name: Green Bananas (Matooke)
ingredients.notes: Peeled and kept in salted water to prevent browning

ingredients.name: Dry Beans (Nambale or Red Kidney Beans)
ingredients.notes: Soaked overnight or for at least 4 hours

steps.instruction: Drain the soaked beans and rinse them thoroughly. Place them in a large pot with 4 cups of water.
Bring the beans to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 45-60 minutes until they are partially tender but not fully cooked.

cooking_indicators.texture: Beans should be soft but still hold their shape

steps.instruction: While beans are cooking, peel the matooke using plastic bags or banana leaves (traditional method) to protect your hands from staining. Cut into large chunks.
Keep the peeled matooke in salted water to prevent browning until ready to use.
In a separate small pan, heat cooking oil over medium heat. Add chopped onions and saut√© until translucent.
Add minced garlic and grated ginger. Cook for 1 minute until fragrant.
Add tomato paste and stir for 1 minute to cook out the raw flavor.
Add chopped tomatoes, curry powder, chili pepper (if using), and beef seasoning. Cook for 5-7 minutes until tomatoes break down and form a thick sauce.
When beans are partially cooked, add the tomato sauce mixture to the beans in the large pot. Stir to combine.
Drain the matooke and add them to the pot, nestling them into the bean mixture.
Add salt and the remaining 2 cups of water. The liquid should come about halfway up the matooke.
Cover the pot tightly and simmer on low heat for 45-60 minutes. Do not stir vigorously - instead, gently shake the pot occasionally.

cooking_indicators.olfactory: A rich, savory aroma will develop

steps.instruction: After 45 minutes, check for doneness. The matooke should be very tender and easily mashable, and the beans should be completely soft.

cooking_indicators.texture: Matooke should be soft enough to mash with a fork

steps.instruction: Once cooked, gently mash some of the matooke into the bean sauce to thicken it. The katogo should have a thick, stew-like consistency.
Taste and adjust seasoning if needed. The katogo should be savory and well-balanced.
Serve hot in bowls, ensuring each portion has both matooke and beans with plenty of the flavorful sauce.

serving_suggestions: Serve as a complete meal on its own, traditionally for breakfast. Katogo is often eaten with a spoon directly from the bowl. Some people enjoy it with a side of avocado or steamed leafy greens. It can also be served with a wedge of lime or lemon for extra freshness. Perfect with a cup of black tea or coffee.
